subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Accident Prevention and Investigation in Occupational Systems
headline: Learn the fundamentals of occupational accident investigation and prevention in this free online course.
description: This introductory course offers a general overview of accident prevention and investigation procedures in various occupational settings. By taking this course, you will equip yourself with the knowledge of the methods used to prevent accidents and injuries in the workplace. You will also learn about the levels of risk control laid out by the pyramid of the 'hierarchy of controls' followed by techniques to reduce workplace accidents.
courseDescription:
Accidents and incidents are prevalent in various industries and their workplaces. Some of the primary reasons for these mishaps are lack of preventive measures, non-compliance to safety standards and lack of education among the employees. Moreover, many employers fail to perform their part regarding the safety of their employees, thus contributing to social and economic losses along with the loss of human lives. Another reason for these incidents is the lack of competent professionals in this field.

These factors cost millions of dollars to organisations and enterprises every year when combined. Keeping this in mind, the experts at ExoExcellence have created a course to address this gap in knowledge on accident investigation and prevention in occupational settings. We have made accident investigation a part of this course because it is a vital factor in determining the cause of the accident. Moreover, thorough and transparent investigations help organisations prevent accidents from happening again in the future.

We have divided the content of this course into two modules containing three base topics. The first module includes topics regarding common accidents and injuries in the workplace. It also discusses those accidents that are specific to certain industries. The second module presents the methods for investigating workplace accidents and how to control their occurrence by implementing the pyramid of 'hierarchy of controls'. The course also contains various graphics, statistics and a brief assessment to increase your interest in learning.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Identify different reasons why accidents happen in the workplace
    • Indicate the industries with the highest risk of workplace injuries
    • Evaluate the methods by which accidents in the workplace can be prevented
    • Expain the common workplace injuries across various industries
    • Discuss the importance of knowing the workplace hazards
    • Recognize the correct technique for lifting heavy objects in the workplace

  • Introduction to Accidents

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Accidents and incidents can happen anytime, anywhere. Workplaces and offices are some of the most typical places of their occurrence. Even today, with sophisticated and modern technologies employed to prevent incidents, thousands of these events occur daily, worldwide. They are not only a source of morbidity and mortality, they can also cause severe economic losses and property damage.
  • What is an Accident?
  • Any unplanned and unintentional event resulting in personal injury or property damage is called an accident. Examples of accidents include unintended collisions, electrical injuries, getting hurt by a sharp object, and ingesting poison.
    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Minor Accidents
      An accident is minor if its resultant injury requires little or no treatment at all.
      An accident is minor if its resultant injury requires little or no treatment at all.
    • Major Accidents
      An accident is major if it causes disability (permanent total, or permanent partial or temporary total disability), or fatality.
      An accident is major if it causes disability (permanent total, or permanent partial or temporary total disability), or fatality.

  • Common Injuries Faced in the Workplace

  • Some of the most typical injuries that are faced in a workplace are:

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • Slips and falls
    • Muscle strains
    • Getting struck by workers, equipment, and heavy objects
    • Crashes and collisions
    • Exposure to toxic substances
    • Injuries from fire and explosions

  • Preventing Accidents in the Workplace

  • The unplanned occurrences causing injuries, illness, death, and property/or production loss are known as accidents. Although eliminating the accidents may be impossible, opting for specific plans, preparations, and actions can help reduce their chance of happening.
  • A Simple 4-Step Guide for Preventing Workplace Accidents

  • Lesson Summary

  • Accidents can be classified into two types:
    • Minor Accidents: An accident is minor if its resultant injury requires little or no treatment at all.
    • Major Accidents: An accident is major if it causes a fatality or a permanent total, or permanent partial or temporary total disability.
  • Industries with the Most Risk of Workplace Incidents
    • Manufacturing industry: Common injuries in the manufacturing industry include first-degree burns, bone fractures, and concussions.
    • Construction Industry: Common injuries in the manufacturing industry include occupational asthma and skin conditions
    • Transportation Industry:Musculoskeletal problems and exhaustion are commonly reported problems in the transportation industry

  • Lesson Summary

    • Construction Industry: Common injuries in the manufacturing industry include occupational asthma and skin conditions
    • Transportation Industry:Musculoskeletal problems and exhaustion are commonly reported problems in the transportation industry

    • Construction Industry: Common injuries in the manufacturing industry include occupational asthma and skin conditions

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Identify the three levels of causes of accidents
    • Indicate the roles and responsibilities of investigators regarding accidents in a workplace
    • Analyze the six different levels of the pyramid of hierarchy of controls
    • Define each level of the pyramid of control in simple words
    • Outline the role of PE in the workplace
    • Recall various steps to reduce workplace-related accident injuries at the level of employees and organization
    • Recognize the different aspects of safety and wellness programs in organizations

  • The number of deaths resulting from occupational injuries has recently decreased in the U.S., thanks to prevalent workplace safety practices.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The Three Levels of Accident Causation
    • Basic Causes: Basic Causes of an accident are the result of poor management policies, wrong decisions, personal, or environmental factors. All of these four factors can be gathered under the label of Basic Causes.
    • Indirect Causes: One or more unsafe acts or conditions are the Indirect Cause of the accident. Direct Causes of an accident are the resultant of these Indirect Causes
    • Direct Causes: These causes are at the lowest level and are responsible for transmitting an amount of energy or hazardous material into an object or a person such that it cannot be safely absorbed.
  • Implementation of Safety and Wellness Plan in Organizations
    • Implementation of a safety and wellness Plan
    • Locating vulnerabilities in the safety management system
    • Monitoring of safety measures

    • Direct Causes: These causes are at the lowest level and are responsible for transmitting an amount of energy or hazardous material into an object or a person such that it cannot be safely absorbed.
